item.title: Faafous
item.dc:creator: reahayek
item.description: faafous type design Faafous is a typeface designed as part of the Arabic Type Design Beirut workshop in 2019, lead by Kristyan Sarkis and Lara Captan. This rounded Ruqaa’-based typeface was the result of two weeks of intensive work. Facebook Instagram Linkedin
item.content:encoded:
faafous

type design

Faafous is a typeface designed as part of the Arabic Type Design Beirut workshop in 2019, lead by Kristyan Sarkis and Lara Captan. This rounded Ruqaa’-based typeface was the result of two weeks of intensive work.

item.title: Aziz
item.dc:creator: reahayek
item.description: aziz type design The word Aziz means “Dear” in Arabic. It is also my grandfather’s name, a person with whom I shared my love for Arabic type and the Arabic scripts. This font, being my first Arabic type design project completed during my studies at AUB, was dedicated to him. Aziz is a Naskh-based display… Read More »Aziz
item.content:encoded:
aziz

type design

The word Aziz means “Dear” in Arabic. It is also my grandfather’s name, a person with whom I shared my love for Arabic type and the Arabic scripts. This font, being my first Arabic type design project completed during my studies at AUB, was dedicated to him.

Aziz is a Naskh-based display typeface. It’s high contrast and thick baseline make it suitable for headers, titles, posters and other big-scale applications.

Facebook
Instagram
Linkedin

item.description: Dongola limited editions Motions Dongola is a Beirut-based publication house that creates art books offering unconventional perspectives on art and contemporary topics in the MENASA region today. The company kickstarted at the end of 2017. Its logo and visual identity were created by Reza Abedini, and the motion graphics below were made to announce the launch… Read More »Dongola Limited Editions
item.content:encoded:
Dongola limited editions

Motions

Dongola is a Beirut-based publication house that creates art books offering unconventional perspectives on art and contemporary topics in the MENASA region today. The company kickstarted at the end of 2017. Its logo and visual identity were created by Reza Abedini, and the motion graphics below were made to announce the launch of their social media account.

Art Direction by Reza Abedini.

IDENTITY REVEAL MOTIONS

CITIES UNDER QUARANTINE – PROJECT

sifr – PROJECT

item.title: Typoem
item.dc:creator: reahayek
item.description: typoem Motions Typoem was an Arabic Typography Workshop lead by Reza Abedini, during which the participants had the chance to experiment with Arabic Typography using the Arabic poems of their choice. The artworks produced were later bound into a publication that was launched and sold at the exhibition space Dar El-Nimer. Art direction by Reza… Read More »Typoem
item.content:encoded:
typoem

Motions

Typoem was an Arabic Typography Workshop lead by Reza Abedini, during which the participants had the chance to experiment with Arabic Typography using the Arabic poems of their choice. The artworks produced were later bound into a publication that was launched and sold at the exhibition space Dar El-Nimer.

Art direction by Reza Abedini

item.title: The Mediator
item.dc:creator: reahayek
item.description: the mediator Motions A title sequence of 47 seconds for a television series based on Meg Cabot’s fictional book The Mediator. The animation is, in parts, done in stop-motion. The diary reflects the main character – a teenager who leads a double life: average high-school girl by day, fighting the dead by night. Facebook Instagram Linkedin
item.content:encoded:
the mediator

Motions

A title sequence of 47 seconds for a television series based on Meg Cabot’s fictional book The Mediator. The animation is, in parts, done in stop-motion. The diary reflects the main character – a teenager who leads a double life: average high-school girl by day, fighting the dead by night.

item.title: Ident

item.description: ident Motions An ident of 17 seconds that reveals a logo, designed for a conceptual printing press. This animation was done as part of a Motion Graphics course, while completing my BFA is Graphic Design. Facebook Instagram Linkedin

ident

Motions

item.title: City Debates 2018
item.dc:creator: reahayek
item.description: City debates 2018 Motions City Debates is a yearly conference organized by the Masters in Urban Planning & Policy and Masters in Urban Design Programs at the American University of Beirut. City Debates 2018 held the topic of “Architecture-As-Urbanism.”​ Art Direction by Reza Abedini. Facebook Instagram Linkedin
item.content:encoded:
City debates 2018

Motions

City Debates is a yearly conference organized by the Masters in Urban Planning & Policy and Masters in Urban Design Programs at the American University of Beirut. City Debates 2018 held the topic of “Architecture-As-Urbanism.”​

item.title: Jules et Jim
item.dc:creator: reahayek
item.description: Jules et Jim posters An announcement poster for an outdoor screening of the French movie Jules et Jim by Francois Truffaut. The three colors, as well as the interlace of words, create the same atmosphere of bonding formed by the love triangle depicted in the movie. Facebook Instagram Linkedin
item.content:encoded:
Jules et Jim

posters

An announcement poster for an outdoor screening of the French movie Jules et Jim by Francois Truffaut. The three colors, as well as the interlace of words, create the same atmosphere of bonding formed by the love triangle depicted in the movie.

item.title: Antara
item.dc:creator: reahayek
item.description: antara posters This country is a furnished apartment or “هذه البلاد شقة مفروشة” is a poem written by the Syrian poet Nizar Qabbani. The poem talks about the ruler of Qabbani’s country, whom he recurrently compares to the fictional character Antara or “عنترة”. This tryptic series of posters experiments with Arabic typography while highlighting the… Read More »Antara
item.content:encoded:
antara

posters

This country is a furnished apartment or “هذه البلاد شقة مفروشة” is a poem written by the Syrian poet Nizar Qabbani. The poem talks about the ruler of Qabbani’s country, whom he recurrently compares to the fictional character Antara or “عنترة”. This tryptic series of posters experiments with Arabic typography while highlighting the omnipresence, dictatorially ruling Antara that Qabbani speaks of in this poem.

Facebook
Instagram
Linkedin
